image.altText: John Pesutto and Moira Deeming in a composite image.

props.synopsis: Moira Deeming took the stand in the first week of the defamation case brought against her former boss, Victorian Liberal leader John Pesutto.

title.children: The first week of the Victorian Liberals' defamation trial thrust a secret recording into the public sphere

image.altText: Police tape at a crime scene

props.synopsis: Four teenagers have been arrested after allegedly threatening a man in a Melbourne shopping centre car park with a pair of pliers and pulling him out of his vehicle.

title.children: Teenagers as young as 14 arrested after allegedly threatening man with pliers and stealing his car

image.altText: People are seen carrying umbrellas as rain falls in Sydney

props.synopsis: A near-nationwide soaking will drench every Australian state and territory this week, including potential record heavy falls in the north-west tropics.

title.children: Rare September soaking for all Australian states this week could break rain records and signal wet spring and summer

image.altText: Rocco standing in front of a neon sign reading 'Pellegrini's' with his arms folded.

props.synopsis: Rocco Eliche will hang up his apron for the last time today after 50 years at the iconic Melbourne coffee bar Pellegrini's.

title.children: 'Moustache and a big smile': Pellegrini's in Melbourne farewells long-term server Rocco Eliche

image.altText: A restaurant is packed with people eating food in a brightly-lit setting

props.synopsis: The South Korean cultural phenomenon shows no signs of slowing as Melbourne announces its official Koreatown.

title.children: How Australia's newest K-town reflects the growing influence of Korea's culture on our cities

image.altText: A smiling man in a puffer vest stands outside a business front.

props.synopsis: Michael Veal is the only doctor in Avoca, which was without a general practice for 12 months before he arrived. But the relief may only be temporary and it's a symptom of an Australia-wide problem.

title.children: GP who saved country town from doctor drought says primary health care has 'driven off a cliff'

image.altText: Steven King speaks to Cats players during a 2024 AFL match.

props.synopsis: Geelong assistant coach Steven King is taken to hospital after suffering a medical episode as the Cats prepared for Saturday's preliminary final against the Brisbane Lions.

title.children: 'Quite confronting': Cats assistant coach hospitalised after collapsing at training ahead of prelim final

image.altText: A close-up of Sparkly Bear's face, which shows a bespectacled bronze bear face with pursed lips.

props.synopsis: The owners of a shopping centre in Melbourne's inner-north say they have been told a beloved bear statue that was stolen from the precinct is unlikely to be returned.

title.children: Sparkly Bear 'unlikely' to be returned, as locals share outpouring of sadness over theft of statue

image.altText: A composite of three photos. The Great Stupa white building with gold dome, a man posing in the Big Wave, Cape Clear lighthouse.

props.synopsis: When planning a road trip, the journey can be just as important as the destination, so look out for these impressive landmarks across Victoria.

title.children: Taking a road trip? Don't miss out on these five quirky rest stops

image.altText: People stand around large amounts of dirt and rubbish, near a missile strike site.

props.synopsis: Lebanon's health ministry says 66 other people were also injured after the IDF struck a building in the suburb of Dahiyeh, a stronghold for the militant group Hezbollah.

title.children: At least 14 killed in IDF strike in Beirut, including top Hezbollah commander Ibrahim Aqil

image.altText: A series of blue texts saying "are you okay" appear on the screen next to a Lebanese flag.

props.synopsis: Fears and anxieties echo across the Lebanese diaspora as they watch from afar after a series of explosions kill dozens and injure thousands in Lebanon.

title.children: 'A lot of them are civilians': Pager explosions in Lebanon have diaspora fearful and frustrated

image.altText: Mike Burgess wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: Heavily redacted government briefing documents made public reveal ASIO checked all Palestinian visa holders in March, with "no adverse information identified".

title.children: ASIO referred every Palestinian visa holder, testing Coalition's claims of lax screening

image.altText: Side by side photos of Anthony Albanese and Adam Bandt, both in dark suits, ties and spectacles

props.synopsis: Australia's housing crisis is a perfect storm of issues that requires a reset of the housing debate which so far has not been able to happen in the poisonous political competition of 2024.

title.children: Fixing Australia's housing crisis requires a reset of the poisonous debate that's clogged up politics

image.altText: William Swale at court

props.synopsis: Victoria's Office of Public prosecutions could use a rare legal tactic to force William Swale back before the courts, after 14 charges over the deadly Daylesford pub crash were thrown out by a Ballarat court.

title.children: Daylesford crash driver could face further court action, as prosecutors to 'carefully review' decision to dismiss charges

image.altText: Four children run and celebrate, one does a flip

props.synopsis: Australia's Western Desert teams are preparing to battle for glory on red dirt ovals, where boundaries are marked with flour, players compete barefoot, and champions are made.

title.children: More than 2,700km from the MCG, finals fever grips one of the nation's most remote leagues

image.altText: Rahmanullah Gurbaz raises his bat to celebrate a 50

props.synopsis: Afghanistan continues its meteoric rise to becoming a powerful cricketing nation by taking an unassailable series lead over South Africa.

title.children: Months after stunning Australia, Afghanistan creates more cricket history with series win over South Africa

image.altText: A graphic of the glove with solar panels and an electric vehicle in the foreground.

props.synopsis: Renewable technologies are gathering speed, putting the world within reach of falling greenhouse gas emissions. Climate experts say they "struggle to wrap their heads around" the sheer size, scale and speed of the current transition.

title.children: The world reaches a historic tipping point thanks to 'the most rapid change since the Industrial Revolution'

image.altText: Mark Scott looks serious as he speaks, in front of a blue "National Press Club" backdrop.

props.synopsis: The head of the University of Sydney has apologised to Jewish students and staff, admitting he "failed them" in his handling of an eight-week pro-Palestinian student encampment.

title.children: 'We have failed them': University of Sydney vice-chancellor apologises to Jewish students

image.altText: A woman and her son looking out at a beach

props.synopsis: The number of "accidental" homeschooled students is increasing across Australia, and some families are reporting positive outcomes.

title.children: Australia has a growing number of 'accidental' homeschool students, and COVID is only part of the reason

image.altText: Half of a white metal hull with debris around it lies on the ocean floor, with blue water and harsh light

props.synopsis: The catastrophic implosion of the Titan submersible deep in the waters of the Atlantic Ocean in 2023 could have been prevented, a hearing into the tragedy has been told.

title.children: Years of red flags preceded Titan sub implosion: All the key takeaways from this week's testimony on the disaster

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch helped out of the back seat of a car by his wife and a security guard

props.synopsis: If the latest instalment in the Murdoch family saga tells us anything, it is that while the patriarch no longer jokes about immortality, he's at least retained his dark sense of humour.

title.children: War of the words breaks out over Rupert's desperate bid to control beyond the grave

image.altText: Two men, one bald with his hand placed on his heart, and another with a green shirt with a hand to his face

props.synopsis: The head coaches of the Socceroos and Matildas have departed within months of each other, leaving mixed legacies and plenty of questions in their wake.

title.children: Arnold and Gustavsson's legacies will be defined by what Australian football does next

image.altText: A man waves Sri Lanka's flag during a campaign rally at night.

props.synopsis: Two years since thousands of protesters swarmed the presidential palace in Sri Lanka, voters are heading to the polls, where three presidential candidates have emerged as frontrunners for the first time.

title.children: Sri Lanka's 'social contract is in pieces'. How will they vote in the presidential election?

image.altText: Hannah sitting in the sun smiling with a drink in hand.

props.synopsis: The man accused of murdering 23-year-old Victorian woman Hannah McGuire has elected to fast-track the matter to the Supreme Court for trial.

title.children: Hannah McGuire accused pleads not guilty to murder, will stand trial in Supreme Court

image.altText: Black and white picture of a man wearing a bow tie and suit jacket sitting in a car, waving at the crowds

props.synopsis: These US musicians were recruited as 'jazz ambassadors'. Unbeknownst to them, some played a role in a coup in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in 1961.

title.children: Louis Armstrong was sent to the Congo as a jazz ambassador. His concert was used as cover for a coup

image.altText: Callum Mills shares a hug with Will Hayward

props.synopsis: Sydney coach John Longmire has a few selection headaches on his plate in the lead-up to his second grand final in the space of three seasons.

title.children: Swans set for major grand final selection call on Callum Mills as veteran defender sweats on MRO fate

image.altText: A young mother and child playing inside a house

props.synopsis: Parenting programs are available throughout the country, but experts say a lack of awareness, societal expectations and stigmas might be stopping more people from signing up.

title.children: Inoka wanted to be a better parent for her daughter. She is among many Australians signing up for parenting courses

image.altText: A Modular Advanced Armed Robotic System in the field.

props.synopsis: They are the stuff of 80s sci-fi blockbuster, The Terminator, but now lethal autonomous weapon systems are being used in conflict zones around the world. One woman is trying to stop them.

title.children: Autonomous weapon systems boil human beings down to data points. One woman is determined to ban their use

image.altText: A piloted jet flies in the air with streaks of smoke behind it

props.synopsis: By flying jets faster than the speed of sound low over cities, the Israeli military has been accused of "terrifying" the residents of Beirut and Lebanon.

title.children: What is a sonic boom, and why has Israel repeatedly created them over Beirut?

image.altText: A nightclub with people dancing around a DJ under a red backlight with a disco ball.

props.synopsis: Venue managers say the cost of operating is making it harder for small, diverse businesses to exist in Brisbane, putting the safe space they provide to vulnerable communities at risk.

title.children: In a unpredictable live music industry, queer venues are fighting to keep their doors open

image.altText: Mpox

props.synopsis: It is possible to end the mpox outbreak in Burundi within weeks, a UN health official says, depending on getting adequate resources and battling stigma associated with the disease.

title.children: Burundi mpox outbreak could be stopped 'within a very few weeks', UNICEF says

image.altText: Ballarat Grammar School

props.synopsis: A staff member from Ballarat Grammar in Victoria is recovering in hospital after losing consciousness on a school scuba diving trip at St Leonards.

title.children: Staff member resuscitated after near drowning on private school scuba trip

image.altText: Three young women walk down a set of stairs surrounded by fluorescent lights in Macau

props.synopsis: Macau has long been a gambler's paradise but has its luck run out?

title.children: The casino capital of the world is trying to kick its gambling addiction
